data.title: Paul McCartney Early Life, Musical Career, Facts & Worksheets
data.meta_description: Paul McCartney is a singer-songwriter, and former member of the legendary band, the Beatles. Click for more facts and worksheets.
data.text:
Worksheets /People /Paul McCartney Facts & Worksheets

Not ready to purchase a subscription? Click to download the free sample version Download sample

Table of Contents

Paul McCartney is a singer-songwriter, and former member of the legendary band, the Beatles. He is also a well-known performer and one of the most successful soloists who remains active in the music industry today.

See the fact file below for more information on Paul McCartney or alternatively, you can download our 35-page Paul McCartney worksheet pack to utilise within the classroom or home environment.

Key Facts & Information

Early Life

James Paul McCartney, or more popularly known as Paul McCartney, was born on June 18, 1942, in Liverpool, England, at Walton Hospital, where his mother had qualified as a maternity nurse.

Paul was the eldest child of Mary Patricia and James McCartney.

He has a younger brother named Peter Michael and a step-sister, Ruth.

His father, a cotton merchant, a trumpet player, and a pianist, encouraged Paul to study music, but Paul preferred to learn to play instruments by ear.

From 1947–1949, he attended Stockton Wood Road Primary School and then transferred to Joseph Williams Junior School.

He entered the Liverpool Institute grammar school in 1953 as he was one of only three of 90 students who passed the 11-Plus exam.

After a year, he met and became good friends with his schoolmate George Harrison who later became his bandmate.

Paul’s mother died when he was just 14 due to a complication after surgery for breast cancer.

Paul had auditioned for the Liverpool Cathedral choir but was not accepted.

However, he was able to join the St. Barnabas’ Church choir.

When rock and roll became a popular music genre, he exchanged the nickel-plated trumpet he had received from his father for an acoustic guitar as he wanted to sing while playing the instrument.

At first, it was difficult for him to play the guitar right-handed, but inspired by a Slim Whitman concert poster that showed he was left-handed, he reversed the strings on his instrument.

During the 1950s, Paul McCartney excelled in his art assignments, earning him recognition for his works, but his academic record was affected due to his lack of discipline; thereby, hindering him from entering an art school.

Marriage

Paul McCartney had prior relationships before marrying his wife, Linda Eastman.

He had a two-and-a-half-year relationship with Dot Rhone and a five-year relationship with Jane Asher.

Linda Eastman was Paul’s first wife.

She was a popular photographer with various rock bands.

She met the Beatles in 1966 at Shea Stadium and was initially a fan of John Lennon.

On May 15, 1967, Linda and Paul were first formally introduced at The Bag O’ Nails club during a George Fame concert.

In March 1969, they married and had four children, namely Heather (who was Linda’s daughter adopted by Paul), Mary (named after Paul’s mother), Stella (named after Linda’s grandmother), and their youngest, James.

The couple lived a vegetarian life and were animal rights activists.

However, Linda died in 1998 due to breast cancer, and Paul had to seek help from a counselor to cope with his loss.

Paul McCartney remarried in 2002 to former model Heather Mills. They separated in April 2006 and divorced in March 2008.

They had a daughter named Beatrice Milly.

Heather was an active anti-landmine campaigner, and during their married life, Paul joined her campaigns.

On October 9, 2011, Paul married his third wife, Nancy Shevell, in a civil and intimate wedding.

Nancy Shevell works in the transportation industry, being the vice president of the Shevell Group and was a former board member of the New York’s Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

She was 18 years younger than Paul and had known him for several years since both owned houses in the Hamptons.

Humanitarian Works

Paul and Linda were both animal-rights supporters, and upon her death, Paul continued to join and support different animal-rights campaigns and organizations.

With him joining Heather Mills in her anti-landmine campaigns, Paul became a patron of Adopt-A-Minefield.

Paul actively joined various campaigns; he was also an advocate for providing the needs of children with diseases and disorders, and he supported the eradication of poverty.

Apart from the campaigns that Paul supported, he participated in charity events, benefit concerts and donated his songs and sales to different causes.

Career

Paul McCartney idolized Little Richard, and he loved the American rhythm and blues music genre that influenced his music.

His music was also inspired by artists like Elvis Presley, Buddy Holly, Carl Perkins, and Chuck Berry.

His first written and guitar-composed song was “I Lost My Little Girl;” he also created “When I’m Sixty Four” for the piano.

He joined a talent contest at Butlin’s Filey Holiday Camp and performed “Long Tall Sally” in his first-ever public performance.

John Lennon and his band named the Quarryman first met Paul McCartney on July 6, 1957, and had soon invited Paul to become their rhythm guitarist.

John and Paul developed a close working relationship and close friendship, as they both empathized with the untimely death of their mothers.

In 1958, George Harrison also joined the band as lead guitarist and Stuart Sutcliffe in 1960 as bassist.

They had come up with many different band names until August 1960, when they settled with the “Beatles.”

In the same year, Pete Best also joined them as a drummer.

Shortly after, Stuart Sutcliffe left the band to pursue his art career, and although he was hesitant, Paul McCartney replaced him.

When they performed as a backup band for one of Tony Sheridan’s songs, they caught the attention of Brian Epstein.

In January 1962, he started managing them under the EMI- Parlophone label.

Their drummer, Pete Best, was known for his looks rather than his talent.

Unambitious enough, the band decided to replace him with a permanent member, Ringo Starr, who used to be his stand-in drummer.

Paul and John were the songwriters of the group.

From October 1962 to May 1970, the two had published about 180 songs.

During the years that the Beatles was active, they released hit songs such as “Love Me Do,” “I Saw Her Standing There,” “She Loves You,” “I Want to Hold Your Hand,” and “Can’t Buy Me Love,” which were all co-written by John and Paul.

Their fans rapidly increased and their hysteria became known as Beatlemania.

They also released Paul’s composition “Yesterday,” which is one of the most covered songs in music history.

However, with their increasing popularity, the group also faced misunderstandings, and there was a growing feud between John and Paul.

Despite their differences, they continued performing as a group.

Music produced by the Beatles was not limited to ballads and love songs; they also released songs from other genres, which featured on their 1966 album “Revolver.”

Their last live show was also in 1966, but they continued making albums and music.

The death of their manager, Brian Epstein, in August 1966 left the band anxious about their career and their future.

Paul McCartney filled in the position as manager and acting leader of the band.

The band produced a film entitled “Magical Mystery Tour” that Paul mainly directed.

The soundtrack received praise, but unfortunately, the film received critical responses from the public.

An animated film of the Beatles based on Paul’s 1966 composition “Yellow Submarine” was also released, but unlike their former songs, the popularity of the music from this film was short-lived.

Despite the band’s success, the feud among the members continued causing a lapse in their relationship.

The famous album “Abbey Road” was the last one they released.

Upon the disbandment of the Beatles, Paul McCartney became depressed, and his wife was there to help him; he made a come-back as a soloist.

His first album, “McCartney,” released in 1970, gained so much popularity that it became a top-selling album in the U.S.

His second album, “Ram”, also became a hit album after the release of “McCartney.”

He formed the band Wings together with Linda McCartney, Denny Laine, Denny Seiwell, and Henry McCullough.

Their first concert performance was at the University of Nottingham in 1972.

In the 1970s, the Wings concert tour became the best-selling pop act beating Elton John’s record.

Over time, the members changed, but Wings remained successful and achieved several accomplishments.

In 1981, Paul decided to take a new music career path and eventually disbanded when Denny Laine quit due to issues about royalties and salaries.

Paul McCartney continued performing solo with several opportunities to showcase and expand his musical abilities and talent.

Paul had the chance to collaborate with many notable musicians such as Stevie Wonder and Michael Jackson, performed in concerts, wrote and co-wrote several compositions, released more songs, starred in a musical and even ventured into orchestral music.

Paul took a four-year hiatus in his solo career to complete Apple’s “Beatles Anthology” with George Harrison, Ringo Starr, and George Martin.

He continued releasing albums, performing unannounced at his late wife’s concert tribute, “Concert for Linda.”

Paul is famous as a versatile artist and for his ability to play different instruments and create chart-topping songs despite being unable to read music or understand musical theory.

Paul McCartney remains an active solo performer who has an exceptional influence in the music industry.

Art

In 1983, Paul began studying painting and held an exhibition in 1999 in Siegen Germany featuring portraits of John Lennon, Andy Warhol, and David Bowie.

He also wrote and published books such as “Blackbird Singing” (Faber & Faber), “High in the Clouds: An Urban Furry Tail,” “The Observer,” and “Hey Grandude!”

He produced, directed, and hosted various shows such as “Rupert and the Frog Song” and “Tropic Island Hum,” “The Real Buddy Holly Story,” and “Grateful Dead.”

Drug Abuse

The members of the Beatles were said to use drugs during their performances to keep their energy high when they were performing for long hours.

Paul took various drugs and became the first member to discuss the issue with the public.

He was fined a couple of times and arrested for drug possession.

He was also convicted for illegal cultivation because he grew marijuana plants on his farm.

In 2015, he quit cannabis because he wanted to become an example for his grandchildren.

John Lennon and Paul McCartney

In 1980, upon the death of John Lennon, Paul McCartney was mobbed by reporters when he was leaving the recording studio.

Reporters asked him for his reaction, to which he replied, “It’s a drag.”

He received criticism for his response but explained himself by saying that he meant no disrespect and that he was just unable to express his feelings due to shock and sadness.

Paul McCartney could only cry on the evening of John Lennon’s passing, and he also mentioned that his death brought fear to the former members of the Beatles.

In 1981, Paul joined George Harrison’s tribute to John Lennon and sang “All Those Years Ago” as a backup with Ringo Starr playing the drums.

Paul also released a song in 1982 entitled “Here Today,” a tribute song to his and John’s friendship.

Achievements

Paul McCartney garnered various awards and achievements throughout his career as a soloist and member of the Beatles.

Two of his achievements include being admitted to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and being listed twice in the “Guinness Book of Records” as the most honored composer and performer in music and as the most successful songwriter.

His songs were always chart-toppers, and some of his most notable recognitions include: a knighthood from Queen Elizabeth II and Legion d’Honneur for services in music, gaining a star in the Hollywood Walk of fame, being presented an Honorary Fellowship of the Royal College of Music by Prince Charles, and appointed as a Member of the Order of the British Empire.
